results.title: Arthur: Arthur's first sleepover
results.brief_description: Arthur is a young aardvark. His animated stories are based on the books “Arthur Adventure” by Marc Brown. Three episodes of “Arthur” featuring the aardvark and his family and his friends are on this video. His adventures are that of an ordinary eight year old. “Arthur’s first sleepover” has Arthur and his friends camping in the backyard, “Arthur’s New Years Eve” is when Arthur finds out what all the fuss is about and in “Arthur’s Family Vacation” the whole family take an exciting trip together.

results.title: Arthur Penn: the director during the filming of "Little Big Man"
results.creator_credit: Elliott Erwitt and Elliott Erwitt Enterprises
results.brief_description: A portrait of the director Arthur Penn at work on the film ‘Little Big Man’. Using extracts from the film and footage shot behind-the-scene this film illustrates the two main problems involved in the production of a film, the relationship between director and star and the insertion of the director’s personal convictions into his film.

results.title: Arthur Miller and 'The Crucible'
results.brief_description: Using excerpts from Arthur Miller’s play “The Crucible” and dramatisations of the McCarthy trials in the United States in the 1950’s, this program looks at the basic ideas in the drama and examines its place in the playwright’s development. Draws parallels between writing and life experiences and art reflecting reality.

results.title: Arthur Miller
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Writers of today”.
A reissue of a program made in the 50’s for the Educational Television & Radio Center in the United States. Playwright, Arthur Miller, (“The Crucible”, “Death of a salesman”, “From the bridge”) is interviewed by Walter Kerr, drama critic with the New York Herald Tribune. Miller explains his views on live theatre, the need he sees for drama which transcends classes and communicates with all levels of society, and his abhorrence for obscure “literary” drama.

results.title: Arthur C Clarke presents the colours of infinity
results.creator_credit: Nigel Lesmoir-Gordon, Paul Sinclair and Gordon Films
results.brief_description: The subject of this video is the recent discovery in New York by Dr Benoit Mandelbrot of the Mandelbrot Set. This discovery led to the development of a new mathematical discipline- fractal geometry. Mandelbrot’s discovery was aided by the development of the silicon chip in the 1970’s. It was in the 1980’s, assisted by a super computer at IBN laboratories in New York that Mandelbrot’s startling discovery was made. Author and inventor Dr Arthur C Clarke explores the Mandelbrot Set and fractal world along with fellow colleagues Dr Benoit Mandelbrot, Professor Stephen Hawking, Dr Michael Barnsley and Professor Ian Stewart. Clarke (who wrote the script) postulates on the effect these discoveries will have on the future.

results.title: Arthur Boyd: testament of a painter
results.creator_credit: Don Bennetts, Film Victoria, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Don Bennetts Films
results.brief_description: A biographical documentary on one of Australia’s most prolific artists, Arthur Boyd. A charming, gentle, compassionate man, Arthur Boyd was born in 1920 in Murrumbeena, Melbourne, into a family of artists - a family who was known for its eccentricities and stern religious background. In this film we see Arthur chatting with his two young grandsons, providing them with a historical glimpse into their family background through old photographs and stories which have been passed down through the generations, along with his own personal memories of growing up in such a dynasty of “painters, potters, and dreamers”. Boyd was a figurative artist whose work focused on the human condition within the Australian landscape and although he did spend many years out of Australia in London and Europe, his works always retained the Australian spirit. Through stills, home movies, interviews, personal narratives and examples of his paintings, this program endeavours to give an overview of Boyd’s evolving journey through the decades, from his early aspirations to being an actor to finally becoming a serious painter and sculptor. We also see Boyd at work in 1993 as he prepares for a retrospective Exhibition to be held at the Art Gallery of New South Wales. Arthur Boyd has left his legacy to the Australian people by bequeathing three of his properties as a gift to the nation, including the well-known “Bundanon” property which houses artists in residence, an education centre and several of Boyd’s paintings. Arthur Boyd died on 24 April 1999. This superb documentary is a testimony to a truly great artist. Narrated by Oliver Streeton.

results.title: Arthur Boyd: figures in a landscape (Captioned)
results.brief_description: A fascinating program that looks at the painting of Australian artist, Arthur Boyd. For the purposes of this peacefully but not passively photographed documentary, Arthur Boyd completed two different paintings of the same scene, an interior and exterior interpretation of bathers and water-skiers who regularly churn up the tranquillity outside his door, explaining as he works, his inspiration and intention.

results.title: Arthur and Corinne Cantrill interview with Fiona Trigg [excerpt]
results.brief_description:
Arthur and Corinne Cantrill have been making films together since 1960. Initially focusing on documentaries about art they moved on to experimental film in 1969. From 1971 to 2000 they edited and published Cantrills Filmnotes, a journal on film and video art. Their film work and publishing are well-known internationally and have been represented in several film collections.

In this interview with Fiona Trigg, ACMI Exhibitions Assistant Curator, Arthur and Corinne talk about their early days of expanded cinema and their technical and creative processes.
